support_summary: TDP-43 controls the alternative splicing of POLDIP3, a protein that recruits and enhances S6K1 activity to promote mRNA translation. The loss of nuclear TDP-43 function leads to an increase in a POLDIP3 splice variant that is less efficient in activating the mTOR/S6K1 cascade, thereby impairing translation and cell growth in neuronal contexts.

functions.cellular_process: TDP-43 regulates the splicing of POLDIP3, which acts as a scaffold to bring S6K1 to newly synthesized mRNAs, enhancing their translation. A loss of nuclear TDP-43 function increases a POLDIP3 splice variant (variant-2) that is less effective at promoting S6K1-mediated translation in neuronal cells, leading to reduced cell size.
functions.effect_description: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 function indirectly impairs S6K1-dependent translation and cell growth by altering the isoform ratio of the upstream regulator POLDIP3.
biological_consequence: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 → Increased POLDIP3 exon 3 skipping → POLDIP3 variant-2 fails to recruit S6K1 to mRNA → Downregulation of mTORC1/S6K1-mediated translation → Reduced neuronal cell size
specific_effects: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 function results in an increased ratio of POLDIP3 variant-2 to variant-1.
POLDIP3, also known as SKAR, links pre-mRNA splicing to mTOR/S6K1-mediated enhanced translation efficiency of spliced mRNAs.
In neuronal cells, the TDP-43-induced shift in POLDIP3 splicing leads to a downregulation of the mTOR/S6K1 pathway.
